q: What is high blood pressure?
a: High blood pressure, also known as hypertension, is a condition where the force of blood against the walls of the arteries is too high. It can lead to serious health problems if left untreated.

q: What are the risks of high blood pressure?
a: High blood pressure can increase the risk of heart disease, heart attacks, strokes, heart failures, kidney disease, and vascular dementia.

q: How can I check my blood pressure?
a: You can have your blood pressure checked at your GP surgery, pharmacies, as part of your NHS Health Check, or using a home blood pressure monitor.

q: What factors increase the risk of high blood pressure?
a: Factors that can increase the risk of high blood pressure include being overweight, consuming too much salt and not enough fruits and vegetables, lack of exercise, excessive alcohol or caffeine intake, smoking, stress, age over 65, having a relative with high blood pressure, being of black African or Black Caribbean descent, and living in a deprived area.

q: What are the treatment options for high blood pressure?
a: Treatment options for high blood pressure include lifestyle changes such as a healthy diet, exercise, weight loss, reducing salt intake, and quitting smoking. Medications may also be prescribed by a doctor.

q: What lifestyle changes can help reduce blood pressure?
a: Reducing salt intake, having a healthy diet, cutting back on alcohol, losing weight, exercising regularly, cutting down on caffeine, and quitting smoking can help reduce blood pressure.

q: What are the common medicines for high blood pressure?
a: Common medicines for high blood pressure include ACE inhibitors, angiotensin-2 receptor blockers (ARBs), calcium channel blockers, diuretics, beta blockers, alpha blockers, and other diuretics. The specific medicine recommended will depend on individual factors.

q: How can I help improve the website?
a: You can help improve the website by answering a survey about your visit.

q: When should adults get their blood pressure checked?
a: All adults over 40 years old are advised to have their blood pressure checked at least every 5 years.

q: What can high blood pressure do to the body?
a: High blood pressure can put extra strain on blood vessels, heart, and organs like the brain, kidneys, and eyes. It can increase the risk of serious health conditions such as heart disease, strokes, heart failure, kidney disease, and vascular dementia.

q: What is high blood pressure?
a: High blood pressure, also known as hypertension, is a condition where there is an abnormally high force of blood against the walls of the arteries, which can lead to serious health problems.

q: What are the risks of high blood pressure?
a: High blood pressure can increase the risk of heart disease, heart attacks, strokes, heart failure, kidney disease, vascular dementia, and other health conditions.

q: How can I check my blood pressure?
a: To check your blood pressure, you can visit your GP surgery, a pharmacy, or use a home blood pressure monitor. It is recommended for adults over 40 to have their blood pressure checked regularly.

q: What factors increase the risk of high blood pressure?
a: Several factors can increase the risk of high blood pressure, including being overweight, consuming too much salt and not enough fruit and vegetables, lack of exercise, excessive alcohol or caffeine, smoking, stress, age, family history, ethnic background, and certain underlying health conditions or medications.

q: What are the treatment options for high blood pressure?
a: Treatment for high blood pressure may involve lifestyle changes, such as a healthy diet, regular exercise, reducing salt and alcohol intake, weight loss, and quitting smoking. In some cases, medications may also be prescribed.

q: What lifestyle changes can help lower blood pressure?
a: Making lifestyle changes such as reducing salt intake, having a healthy diet, limiting alcohol consumption, losing weight, exercising regularly, reducing caffeine intake, and quitting smoking can help lower high blood pressure.

q: What are the commonly used medicines for high blood pressure?
a: Medicines commonly used to treat high blood pressure include ACE inhibitors, angiotensin-2 receptor blockers (ARBs), calcium channel blockers, diuretics, beta blockers, alpha blockers, and other diuretics. The specific medicine recommended depends on factors such as the severity of the blood pressure, age, and ethnicity.

q: Are there any available patient resources for understanding high blood pressure treatment options?
a: Yes, the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) provides a patient decision aid to help understand high blood pressure treatment options. You can discuss this with your doctor or find the resource online.

q: Can lifestyle changes alone control high blood pressure?
a: In some cases, lifestyle changes alone, such as a healthy diet, regular exercise, reducing salt and alcohol intake, weight loss, and smoking cessation, can help control high blood pressure. However, medication may also be necessary depending on individual circumstances.

q: How can I help improve the website?
a: If you would like to provide feedback to improve the website, please take a moment to answer some survey questions about your visit.
